entry.title: CSS Blog: ID vs Class, Main Axis vs Cross Axis, Flexbox Properties, Justify Content vs Text Align Center â€”Interview Q&A
entry.summary:
1. CSS ID vs Class What? ID is a unique identifier for an HTML element. Class is a reusable identifier that can be assigned to multiple elements. Use ID when you want to style or manipulate one unique element on the page. Use Class when you want to style or select multiple elements with the same styles. IDs have higher specificity, so they override classes if both are applied to the same element. Classes promote reusable styles and avoid duplication. Feature ID Class Uniqueness Unique per page Can be used on multiple elements Selector syntax #idName .className Specificity Higher Lower Usage Single element styling Group of elements
Header
Box 1
Box 2
#header { background-color: blue; colâ€¦

entry.title: CSS Media Queries: When, What, Why, Which, How, Differences, and Examples
entry.summary:
What is a CSS Media Query?
A CSS Media Query is a technique used in CSS to apply styles conditionally based on the characteristics of the device or viewport displaying the content. It allows you to create responsive designs that adapt to different screen sizes, resolutions, orientations, and more. When you want your website or app to look good on all devices (mobile, tablet, desktop). When you want to change layouts, font sizes, or hide/show elements depending on screen size. When you want to optimize performance by loading or styling content specifically for device capabilities. When you want to implement responsive web design (RWD). To improve user experience on different devices. To ensure your site is accessible and readable on small screens. To avoid horizontal scrolling on mobile dâ€¦

entry.title: ðŸ’ª CSS Flexbox â€” What, When, Why, Which, How, Differences, Examples, and Interview Q\&A
entry.summary:
â“ What is Flexbox?
Flexbox (Flexible Box Layout) is a one-dimensional layout system in CSS used to align and distribute space among items inside a container. It works in either a row or a column, but not both at the same time. Use Flexbox when: You want to align elements horizontally or vertically
You want to space items evenly
You need to build responsive layouts
You want easy alignment without using floats or position
ðŸ’¡ Why is Flexbox Important?
It simplifies layout design
Handles resizing and spacing automatically
Replaces old hacks like float, inline-block, and positioning
Great for navbars, cards, buttons, galleries, footers, and more display: flex; flex-direction justify-content align-items flex-wrap gap flex align-self order flex-grow, flex-shrink, flex-baâ€¦

entry.title: ðŸ“Œ CSS `position` Property â€“ What, When, Why, Where, Which, How + Examples & Interview Q&A
entry.summary:
â“ What is position in CSS?
The position property in CSS defines how an element is placed in the document layout. It controls whether an element follows the normal flow or is manually positioned using top, left, right, and bottom. position?
Use it when you want to: Fix something on screen (like a navbar or button) Layer items (like overlays, modals, tooltips) Place elements relative to a parent or the page position important?
Helps create dynamic, interactive UIs Essential for responsive layout behavior Works with z-index, top, left, etc. for fine control Used in modals, tooltips, sticky headers, buttons, etc. You can apply it to any block, inline, or inline-block element: .box { position: relative; top: 20px; }
Value Description
static Default value. Element follows normâ€¦

entry.title: ðŸ§ LeetCode #56 (Merge Intervals) â€” Needed a Few Tries to Crack It
entry.summary:
ðŸ§ LeetCode #56 (Merge Intervals) â€” Needed a Few Tries to Crack It It took me over 2 hours and 3 failed attempts to solve [LeetCode 56: Merge Intervals]. Why?
Because sometimes the problem description and examples just arenâ€™t enough to guide you â€” and thatâ€™s part of the challenge. Some tricky cases like:
[[1,4],[2,3]]
[[1,4],[0,4]]
kept failing.
I assumed the intervals were always in sorted order â€” they werenâ€™t. Then I peeked at the solution and saw:
sort(intervals.begin(), intervals.end());
That one line changed everything. I paused, dug into how 2D sorting works in C++, and that helped unlock the logic. âœ… How sorting works for 2D vectors
ðŸ—£ï¸ Reading discussions and othersâ€™ code can speed up learning
âœï¸ Writing it by hand helped reinforce the logic ðŸ“¸ Sharing my handwritten notes and final accepted solution in C++:
If you're just starting out too â€” remember: it's okay to take time. The goal is to learn.
ðŸ· Hashtags
LearnInPublic #Cplusplus #LeetCode #ProblemSolving #BeginnerDev #CodingJourney #DeveloperJourney #DSA #Cpp #Debugging #LeetCodeSolutions #ProblemSolvingSkills

entry.title: Convert UTC with Day.JS
Beyond Polly: Custom Voice Cloning on AWS vs. Using Native AWS AI Services
entry.summary: By Todd Bernson, CTO of BSC Analytics, Voice Architect, and Guy Who Politely Declined Pollyâ€™s Help Because He Could Do It Better Himself Letâ€™s get something straight: Amazon Polly is great â€” until it isnâ€™t. If youâ€™re building a chatbot, narrating product updates, or making your app sound vaguely robotic (in a â€œpleasant call centerâ€ way), Polly delivers. Itâ€™s fast, itâ€™s affordable, and it supports multiple languages with all the predictable cheer of a Disney ride operator. But what happens when you want your voice app to sound... like you? Or your CEO? Or your 90-year-old grandfather? What if you need complete control over pronunciation, tone, pause patterns, and the ability to train on custom audio that would make Polly blush? This is where the polite faÃ§ade of managed services starts to fâ€¦

entry.title: ðŸ§± CSS `display` Property â€” What, When, Why, Where, How, and Which
entry.summary:
The display property in CSS is like the foundation of how elements behave on your web page. Whether you're placing a button, text, navbar, or card â€” the display property decides how it will appear and interact. Letâ€™s break it down using the 5W1H method for easy learning and interview prep. display property?
The display property defines how an HTML element should behave in the layout â€” as a block, inline, grid, flex, etc. It controls whether elements stack, sit side-by-side, take full width, or just wrap their content. display?
Use it whenever you want to: Control layout behavior (horizontal/vertical) Change how elements appear (e.g., from block to inline) Build responsive UIs (with flex or grid) Hide/show elements (display: none) display important?
It determines spacing, alignment, â€¦

entry.title: Role-Based Sidebar Navigation in React Applications
entry.summary:
Building dynamic sidebars is far from trivial. A maintainable and scalable solution requires a modern, well-structured approach â€” especially when dealing with multiple user roles and navigation scenarios. Without solid architecture, hardcoded components quickly become unmanageable as your application grows. Instead of relying on hardcoded items, you can define a sidebar configuration as data and render items dynamically based on user roles. Hereâ€™s a clean and extensible approach using TypeScript: type SidebarItem = { id: string title: string icon: keyof typeof Icons to: string allowedRoles: UserRole[] activeUrls?: string[] }
const sidebarItems: SidebarItem[] = [ { id: "dashboard", title: t("labels.dashboard"), icon: "dashboard", to: "/dashboard", allowedRâ€¦

entry.title: ðŸ” Bidirectional Service-to-Service Communication using Kafka in Spring Boot with Spring Cloud Stream
entry.summary:
In modern microservices architectures, services often need to communicate both ways â€” sending and receiving messages asynchronously. While REST-based synchronous APIs are easy to start with, they don't scale well under high loads or when services are temporarily unavailable. This is where Apache Kafka shines â€” providing durable, fault-tolerant, and decoupled communication through an event-driven model. In this blog, weâ€™ll build a bidirectional communication flow between two Spring Boot microservices using Spring Cloud Stream and Kafka.
Feature Benefit
ðŸ§µ Asynchronous Non-blocking communication
ðŸ” Resilient Retry, Dead-letter topics
ðŸ”Œ Decoupled Producers donâ€™t need to know who consumes the message
ðŸ”„ Bidirectional Services can act as both consumer and producer
ðŸ“¦ Spring Clouâ€¦

entry.title: Who I'm - a Developer With a dream ( And a heavy heart that Never Gave up )
entry.summary:
Hello , Everyone I'm from Tamil Nadu and I recently completed my bachelor's in computer application .life hasn't been easy - I've faced deep emotional battles, family responsibilities and moments where everything felt too heavy to carry. But even when i broke , I never stayed broken .I kept learning , kept dreaming & kept choosing growing . Why I'm Here I joined dev.to to document my journey - not just as a tech learner , but as a human being rebuilding from the ground up . I believe in sharing raw , honest learning , not just polished perfection. Youâ€™ll see posts from me like: What I learned in my classes today Simple Java logic I tried and failed at (and then succeeded!) How coding is helping me heal and move forward My Dream One day, I want to build something meaningful â€” something that helps people feel seen and supported, especially those who feel left out. Tech is not just my career goal; it's my way of creating a life with purpose. ** To Anyone Reading This: ** If youâ€™re also starting, or restarting, or just tired â€” I want to say this:
You donâ€™t need to be perfect to begin.
You just need to begin. Thanks for reading my first post. Iâ€™ll be back tomorrow â€” not to impress, but to express. By Jackcup Crosston
